passage: The Great Pyramid at Giza is one of the world's most amazing landmarks. Rising high above the Sahara Desert in the Giza region of northern Egypt, the Great Pyramid stands some 450 feet into the burning desert sky and occupies an area of 13 acres. The rough climate of the Sahara has actually caused the pyramid to shrink 30 feet from its original height. The pyramid was such an amazing feat of engineering that it remained the tallest structure in the world for over 3800 years! The entire pyramid was originally faced with polished limestone to make it shine brilliantly in the sun. Most Egyptologists, scientists who study ancient Egypt, agree that the Great Pyramid was built around 2560 BC, a little more than 4,500 years ago. It took tens of thousands of workers twenty years to build. The pyramid contains over two million stone blocks. Although most of the blocks weigh two or three tons, some weigh up to 80 tons! The Great Pyramid of Giza was ordered to be built by the Pharaoh Khufu as a magnificent tomb. His vizier (advisor), Hemon, is credited with being the pyramid's architect. Khufu's pyramid is actually part of a complex of pyramids that includes the Pyramid of Khafre, the smaller Pyramid of Menkaure, a variety of smaller pyramids and structures, and the Great Sphinx. The Great Pyramid of Giza is the last remaining of the Seven Wonders of the World.

passage: The Emperor Penguin is the world's largest and tallest penguin. It is also the heaviest penguin, with some individuals recorded at nearly 100 pounds. Adults have a black head, black tail, and black wings. The underparts are dingy white. The sides of the neck are marked with a large golden or yellow stripe. In addition, there is a varying amount of gold on the upper breast. Like most penguins, the Emperor Penguin has thick, waterproof feathers that cover the entire body except for the bill and feet. Emperor Penguins normally live about 20 years in the wild, though some individuals have been recorded at 40 years of age. Diet: Crustaceans, krill, and small fish. Emperor Penguins will dive to depths of 800 feet in search of food. Most dives last 3–6 minutes. Predators: Sharks, Leopard Seals, Orcas. Chicks are vulnerable to predation from South Polar Skuas. Range: The Emperor Penguin is found throughout the Antarctic perimeter. It is the only species of penguin to breed during the Antarctic winter. Breeding takes place about 60 miles from the coast in the Antarctic interior, where temperatures regularly drop to -40°C. The trek from the Antarctic coastline to the breeding grounds was the inspiration for "March of the Penguins". Nesting: Female Emperor Penguins lay a single egg in May or June. After the egg is laid, the female must immediately feed in the ocean. The egg is carefully transferred to the male, who incubates it under a brood patch above his feet. If the egg rolls onto the ice, it freezes instantly. The male incubates the egg for up to 65 days without eating. On cold days, hundreds of males huddle together for warmth. After about two months, the female returns, locates her mate and chick by sound, and regurgitates stored food to feed the chick. The male then takes his turn feeding in the ocean. After about a month, both parents care for the chick until it joins a group (a creche) to stay warm. Status: The population is estimated at about 200,000 breeding pairs and is considered stable.

passage: The Amazon is the world's largest tropical rainforest. It covers nearly 2.8 million square miles — about the size of Australia. The rainforest is nourished by the Amazon River, the second-largest river in the world, which flows through the heart of the region. The forest is essentially the drainage basin for the river and its many tributaries. It consists of four layers, each supporting unique ecosystems and specialized species. The forest floor is the lowest layer. Only about 2% of sunlight reaches here, so very few plants grow. However, the ground is rich with decaying vegetation and animal matter, which decomposers like millipedes and earthworms feed on. Tree roots stay close to these nutrients. Above the forest floor is the understory. Like the floor, it receives only 2–5% of sunlight. Plants here have large, broad leaves to catch light, and there is very little air movement. So, most flowers rely on insects and animals for pollination instead of the wind. Next is the canopy, where much of the rainforest’s action occurs. Leaves here are very dense and filter about 80% of sunlight. Many leaves form “drip tips” that allow water to slide off, preventing mosses or fungi from growing. The canopy is rich in fruit and flowers. Some plants like bromeliads collect water and provide drinking pools for animals and breeding sites for tree frogs. The highest layer is the emergent layer, with the tallest trees rising above the canopy.

However, the ground is rich with decaying vegetation and animal matter, which decomposers like millipedes and earthworms feed on. Tree roots stay close to these nutrients. Above the forest floor is the understory. Like the floor, it receives only 2–5% of sunlight. Plants here have large, broad leaves to catch light, and there is very little air movement. So, most flowers rely on insects and animals for pollination instead of the wind. Next is the canopy, where much of the rainforest’s action occurs. Leaves here are very dense and filter about 80% of sunlight. Many leaves form “drip tips” that allow water to slide off, preventing mosses or fungi from growing. The canopy is rich in fruit and flowers. Some plants like bromeliads collect water and provide drinking pools for animals and breeding sites for tree frogs. The highest layer is the emergent layer, with the tallest trees rising above the canopy.

passage: The great white shark is the largest predatory shark and one of the most feared. It is gray or bluish above and white below. While the largest can grow up to 22 feet and weigh 5,000 pounds, most are between 13–16 feet long and weigh 1,500–2,400 pounds. The great white has massive serrated teeth arranged in rows. When it attacks, it bites its prey and shakes its head side to side, using the teeth like a saw to tear its victim. It often swallows its own teeth during attacks. Diet: Great whites feed on fish, seals, dolphins, porpoises, otters, and turtles. They detect prey using electroreception and smell. Their Ampullae of Lorenzini — special pores — let them sense electromagnetic fields emitted by moving animals. They can detect voltage as small as half a billionth of a volt. Hunting strategies differ by prey. For example, when hunting seals, they ambush from below with such force that both shark and seal may fly out of the water. When hunting elephant seals, they bite and wait for the prey to bleed out. When targeting dolphins, they attack from above to avoid echolocation. Habitat: Found in sub-arctic coastal waters worldwide, with high concentrations off South Africa, Australia, California, and Mexico. Also found in the Adriatic and Mediterranean Seas. Prefer water between 54°F and 75°F. Reproduction: Though never observed giving birth, females are ovoviviparous — young develop in eggs within the mother’s body. They give birth to 8–9 pups, each about five feet long. Maturity occurs at 12 feet for males and 13 for females. Life expectancy is estimated at 40 years, but this may be low. Attacks: Despite fear surrounding them, great whites rarely target humans. Attacks are often due to mistaken identity. They test-bite floating objects out of curiosity. While buoys survive test bites, humans are not so lucky.

passage: The Age of Exploration began in the 1400s when Europeans became desperate to access spices from Asia. Spices were crucial for preserving food but were expensive and dangerous to obtain. To cut costs, European rulers financed expeditions to find sea routes to Asia. Portugal led early exploration efforts. After Bartholomew Dias reached the Cape of Good Hope, Vasco da Gama became the first to sail around Africa and reach India in 1497. Spain later overtook Portugal in exploration. When Portugal rejected Columbus’s idea to sail west to reach Asia, Spain’s King Ferdinand and Queen Isabella financed his journey. Columbus landed on Hispaniola on October 12, 1492, believing he’d reached Asia — though he had actually discovered the Americas. Spain quickly colonized much of the New World. Ponce de Leon discovered Florida. St. Augustine became the first permanent European settlement. Hernando Cortes conquered the Aztecs, and Francisco Pizarro did the same to the Incas. Others like Coronado and de Soto claimed large parts of North America. Balboa claimed the entire Pacific Ocean for Spain. However, Spain’s rise came with brutality — enslaving natives and forcing conversion to Christianity. France also began exploration, with Verrazano and Cartier claiming parts of Canada and the North Atlantic coast. England financed pirates like Sir Francis Drake to raid Spanish ships and later established settlements such as one in North Carolina in 1587. Conflicts between these nations led to major wars, including the defeat of the Spanish Armada by England in 1588 — a key moment that weakened Spain’s power in the New World.

After Bartholomew Dias reached the Cape of Good Hope, Vasco da Gama became the first to sail around Africa and reach India in 1497. Spain later overtook Portugal in exploration. When Portugal rejected Columbus’s idea to sail west to reach Asia, Spain’s King Ferdinand and Queen Isabella financed his journey. Columbus landed on Hispaniola on October 12, 1492, believing he’d reached Asia — though he had actually discovered the Americas. Spain quickly colonized much of the New World. Ponce de Leon discovered Florida. St. Augustine became the first permanent European settlement. Hernando Cortes conquered the Aztecs, and Francisco Pizarro did the same to the Incas. Others like Coronado and de Soto claimed large parts of North America. Balboa claimed the entire Pacific Ocean for Spain. However, Spain’s rise came with brutality — enslaving natives and forcing conversion to Christianity. France also began exploration, with Verrazano and Cartier claiming parts of Canada and the North Atlantic coast. England financed pirates like Sir Francis Drake to raid Spanish ships and later established settlements such as one in North Carolina in 1587. Conflicts between these nations led to major wars, including the defeat of the Spanish Armada by England in 1588 — a key moment that weakened Spain’s power in the New World.
question: What happened first?
correct_answer: Dias explores the Cape of Good Hope
wrong_answers: Vasco da Gama sails to India
Vasco Nunez de Balboa claims the Pacific Ocean for Spain

passage: Huge waves, sometimes known as tsunamis, can cause devastating damage when they crash onto distant shorelines. They may strike under sunny skies and calm seas, appearing without warning. Walls of water 20 to 30 feet high can suddenly rise, crushing buildings and sweeping away unsuspecting people. These waves are typically triggered by submarine (underwater) earthquakes. When such a quake occurs, it creates a tremendous shock that disturbs the deep ocean and forms a massive swell. This swell radiates outward in all directions, forming a series of concentric waves, like the ripples caused when a stone is dropped into water. However, these oceanic waves are enormous — often a mile wide and many feet high. Before World War II, little action was taken to study or prevent the impact of these waves. Afterward, it became clear that earthquakes in places like the Aleutian Islands could create swells that crash ashore with catastrophic force. These waves can travel at speeds of hundreds of miles per hour, explaining how they can hit with so little warning.

wrong_answers: arise under conditions of cold temperature

passage: The first recorded murder in the United States occurred in 1630. John Billington, a resident of the Plymouth Colony in Massachusetts, was hanged for killing a fellow settler named John Newcomen. Billington had reportedly been quarreling with Newcomen for some time before the killing. Billington was a Mayflower passenger and a member of one of the original families who had come to the New World in 1620. Despite his early arrival, he was known as a troublemaker. He defied authority, argued with leaders, and was even charged with contempt and mutiny. Some suspected he had a hand in previous acts of violence or disorder, but no charges stuck until the Newcomen case. The murder shocked the small Plymouth community, which had little experience with violent crime. Billington was tried and found guilty. Though the leaders struggled with the idea of executing a fellow colonist, they ultimately carried out the punishment. His execution was meant to send a message about the seriousness of law and order in the New World.

passage: The island of Saint Maarten, located in the Caribbean Sea, has a rich and complex history. The island is divided into two parts — the northern half is governed by France, and the southern half by the Netherlands. This division has existed peacefully for hundreds of years. Saint Maarten was first inhabited around 4000 BC by Arawak Indians, who were peaceful and agricultural. Around 800 AD, the Carib Indians arrived and conquered the Arawaks. The Caribs were fierce warriors and expert sailors. They dominated much of the Caribbean until the arrival of the Europeans. In 1493, Christopher Columbus sighted the island on his second voyage and claimed it for Spain. However, the Spanish never settled it permanently. In the 1600s, the Dutch established a base there to support their shipping routes, followed by the French. The two countries agreed to divide the island in 1648. This agreement has held, though both sides have changed size over the years due to skirmishes and treaties. The native population declined rapidly under European colonization due to disease, slavery, and conflict. The Caribs, in particular, resisted colonization fiercely but were eventually defeated. Today, Saint Maarten is known for its beautiful beaches, tourism industry, and status as a unique blend of European and Caribbean culture.

passage: The Desert of Maine is a 40-acre stretch of exposed sand dunes located in the northeastern United States, just outside Freeport, Maine. Despite its name, it’s not a true desert, since it receives more than 50 inches of rain per year. Instead, the “desert” was created by poor farming practices. In the 1700s, the land was forested. When settlers arrived, they cleared the trees for farming and planted potatoes. But overgrazing by sheep and poor crop rotation led to soil exhaustion. The topsoil blew away, revealing glacial sand beneath. Over time, the sand expanded, swallowing fences, barns, and even entire fields. In the 1900s, the land was turned into a tourist attraction. Today, visitors come to see the strange landscape, learn about its history, and take photos with buried wagons or covered trees poking out of the sand. Educational exhibits explain how human activity changed the environment so drastically.
question: Why is the Desert of Maine not considered a real desert?
correct_answer: The land doesn’t actually fit the definition of a real desert
wrong_answers: It is located in New England
It’s not located near sand dunes

The topsoil blew away, revealing glacial sand beneath. Over time, the sand expanded, swallowing fences, barns, and even entire fields. In the 1900s, the land was turned into a tourist attraction. Today, visitors come to see the strange landscape, learn about its history, and take photos with buried wagons or covered trees poking out of the sand. Educational exhibits explain how human activity changed the environment so drastically.
question: What effect did grazing sheep have on the land?
correct_answer: It contributed to the land losing its nutrients

passage: There are three major earthquake zones in the world. The first runs along the Pacific Rim, also known as the "Ring of Fire." This includes countries like Japan, Indonesia, and the western coasts of North and South America. The second runs down the west coast of South America. The third extends through parts of Asia and the Middle East. In the United States, the most well-known fault line is the San Andreas Fault in California. Scientists believe that another major earthquake will eventually strike the area. However, it is difficult to predict exactly when. Some experts say the next "big one" could come anytime between now and 8,000 years from now. The largest earthquake in U.S. history did not occur in California but in Alaska in 1964. That quake measured 9.2 on the Richter scale and caused massive damage. Other major earthquakes in the U.S. occurred in 1811–1812 in Missouri, 1906 in San Francisco, and 1971 in California’s San Fernando Valley. Earthquakes are caused by the sudden movement of tectonic plates. These plates make up Earth’s outer shell and are constantly shifting. When stress builds up along a fault line, the energy is released in the form of seismic waves — shaking the ground. Earthquakes under the ocean can also lead to tsunamis.
